captions.text: There's a cuckoo in the woods, Mama.

Music by V.Ovchinnikov
Sound Recordist E.Zelentsova

V.Zubkov as Holin
E.Zharikov as Galtsev

S.Krylov as Katasonych
N.Grinko as Gryaznov

V.Malyavina as Masha
I.Tarkovskaya as Ivan's Mother

The lieutenant told me
to bring him to you.
He was in the river, near the bank.

He says he'll only talk
to the commander.
He's very weak, or else pretending.
Stand near the stove. Who are you?

Well? Say something.
Where are you from?
Tell No.51 at HQ that I'm here.

Take off your pants, too.
Don't be bashful.

None of your business.
And don't shout at me.
You just tell HQ I'm here.

Don't you teach me.
You know where you are?

You'll stay here till
you tell me who you are,

I won't report that you're
here to anyone.
I don't have to prove anything.

Tell No.51 at HQ
that Bondarev's here. Now!
A chap named Bondarev is here.
He wants me to notify HQ.

He says he's from the other side
of the river.

If he doesn't notify No.51,
he'll be held responsible.
See? I did what you asked me to.
He told me to lock you up.
I asked you to tell No.51.
You expect me to contact Army HQ?!

- Let me do it.
- Don't you dare!

Who d'you know
at Army HQ?

Tell Col.Gryaznov I'm here.
At once.
Send his report on to me at once.

Bring in two pails
of hot water,
Go on, wash up. I'll be back soon.
in the day-time in a deep well.
It's night-time now for the star.

No. Go to sleep.
I'll wake you up when they do.
Were you here while I was sleeping?
Did I talk in my sleep?

I never used to talk
in my sleep. Now I don't know.

Katasonych is waiting for you
at the hollow tree!

- You mean you swam across?
- Yes.

I couldn't find our boat
in the dark.

Tell the sentry
not to let anyone in.

- Where are you going?
- For kerosene.

Katasonych is waiting
at the hollow tree.

Waited all night for nothing,
eh, Katasonych?
He couldn't get to the hollow tree.
He said I'll be sent to the rear.

The assault is soon.
I can still be useful.

You said reconnaissance
is most important!

That scouts are
the soul of the front.
I won't go! If you force me to,

I'll run away and join
the partisans.

You're going to a military school.
Understand?
Tell him I'll do a good job, Holin.

You tell him, Katasonych.
I can't go.

All right... Military school,
or a children's home--
It's all the same to me.

The stove and chimney
will stand forever.
Where is it? I put it here.
Could you help me find it?
A nazi shot my old woman, too.
Where can it be? I just had it.
And had a lot of hair.

I'll have the house
all ready for her.
Think I'm going to chase after you?

- Watch your tongue!
- You wanted to join partisans, eh.

Get into the car!
You won't run away again!

- Yes, I will.
- I said get into the car!

I'll run away from
that military school,

just like I did from
the children's home.

"I ran away from Granny,
And from Grandad, too--"
O Lord, will this ever end?

Lakhov and Moroz were killed
because they were big.

I can get through anywhere.
Besides, I'm all alone.
You're not my dad to decide.

There'll be no time for that
when the offensive begins.

Greetings! I've been
looking for you.

You must be stricter
with your subordinates.

But you try to do
everything yourself.

There's a lull now,
and we have time.

When the offensive starts,
there'll be the wounded.
Get the medical service in order.
Report back to me in 2 days.

Don't worry.
Everything'll be in order.

- a boyfriend?
- No. I've never had one.

- Are you from the Ukraine?
- Why do you ask?
No, I come from near Moscow.

Peredelkino station,
20 minutes by the train.

Surikov, the artist,
came from there.

and Chukovsky, too,
grey-haired and lanky.
I find it hard to at first.

Walk the trunk. You said
you're not afraid of anything.

- Let me help you.
- I'll manage.
Let's have a look at your troops.

Give me the defence line map,
Galtsev.
I'll be right back. Wait for me.
Some gunners gave me a record.
They said you had a phonograph.

Damn! Couldn't you have
dug a deeper one?
D'you know who's on the other bank?

- Yeah, I know.
- Can't you bring them here?
It'll take an hour or so.

- Have you got any boats?
- No.

- Why lying?
- What do you need them for?

- You're a bad liar.
- They're for the landing party.
That's what I need them for!
No, a picnic with your phonograph.

Oh, nothing. You've a pretty
doctor's assistant.

I'm sending her away.
She can't cope with the job.
I don't need you here... man!

We took the college
entrance exams together.
I'm so glad I met you!
Where'd you go after the exams?

I looked everywhere.
Now I've found you.

I'm not. I was stuck at HQ
all this time.
I did nothing but read for 3 days.

I got you a spring for
the phonograph at HQ.
He can talk like a real German.

I wanted to take him on
as an interpreter last year.
Now he's in command of a battalion.

- Yes. It's an old engraving.
- They're Germans, all the same.
And this one, on the horse,

I saw one just like him
on a motorcycle.

Look, they're killing the people
here, too.

Yes. He's a German doctor,
or writer.

I saw them burning books
on the square.

The soot was in the air
for 7 days thereafter.

This writer lived about
400 years ago.

If they spot us, our gunners
will keep them down.

We'll leave Ivan a passage
in the swamp.
I'll take one of Galtsev's boats.
I can swim this river 5 times.
How can I take you across?

- Then you don't get a boat.
- We'll commandeer it.

Or I'll report you to
the divisional commander,

and you'll bring it here
on your back.
You stay here and rest up.
Would you give it to me?
Don't be greedy. Give it to him.
It was my buddy's. He was killed.
Let me have it till tonight.

So you're not taking
me across, right?
We'll listen to it after supper.
I'll get you a knife just like it.

The nazis killed
his mother and sister.

His dad was a border guard.
He was killed in action.

He's been through more
than you can imagine.

will adopt him
when the war's over.
He's really good at stealing boats.
He'll never take a bad one.
How many boats have you stolen?
He should be sent to the rear.
A war's no place for children.
If we don't take him across,

Didn't you say you wanted
to adopt him?

Watch out, or I'll report you
to the commander.
Keep cool... that's the main thing.
We have to get him alive.

IN AN HOUR FROM NOW
THEY'LL SHOOT US

Surround the building!
Don't let him out!
Damn! It was our best boat!
Damn! It was our best boat!

Don't be afraid.
It'll soon be over.
I hear you were a partisan.

The nazis surrounded us
in the woods.

They sent me out by plane
to a boarding school.

They only go
for stupid cramming there,

"herbivorous in the life of Man"
and so on.

You ought to go
to a military school.
He's not the only one with brains.

You've done your fighting.
Rest up, go back to school.

Whoever's of use doesn't
rest up in wartime.
Right, but war isn't for boys.

Did you see the Trostyanets
death camp?
You're all at one against me.
So what? Nobody can see them.

Let's have supper
before we start out.

Why didn't he stop by
to wish me good luck?
He couldn't. It was an urgent summons.
They know how badly we need him.

A fine friend!
He could've stopped by.
Will it be just the two of us?

Stop grinning.
You know what I mean.

Volunteered, didn't you?
Are you frightened now?
We billeted the new men, Lieutenant.

I wouldn't take you,
but it's an emergency.

Make up your mind.
No complaints afterwards.
If they learn you crossed the river
I know. But still, he could have--

THERE ARE 8 OF US
ALL UNDER 19

IN AN HOUR FROM NOW
THEY'LL SHOOT US. AVENGE US

They brought the boat here
and had a smoke.

The captain was here.
He was over there.

He started climbing out
of the trench.
And then he slid back down.
We didn't even hear a shot.

The captain said to leave
him here till morning.

Don't discuss it.
Get the oars.
Wait here. I'll be right back.

I'll go a part of the way
with you.

No, you're too big.
They'll catch on.

The gully's clayey.
I'll carry you over.

If the offensive starts,
meet us in Fyodorovka.

I, for one,
really do want my ma.
Are you a louse, or just stupid?

See a doctor about your nerves
when the war's over.

A good rain would wash away
his footprints.

Wait here for me.
I'll go for the boat.

When I come back,
call out to me in German.

You said you could swim
this river 5 times.

- Are things quiet on the bank?
- Yes.
It's the first snow of the year.

He might still be hiding.
Waiting.

Who were you talking to
on the road?
But he does! He is strange.

- What is it, Lieutenant?
- I've come to say good-bye.

I'm transferring her
to a hospital.

It's Goebbels,
his wife and daughters.

and ordered
his body to be burned.
He can show you the place.

He saw him yesterday
and talked to him.

He murdered his family
and committed suicide.

Won't this be the last war
on earth?
I must think of preserving peace.

comments.author: Alexandr Vorontsov

comments.text:
Spoilers ahead!

So was Ivan working for the Germans the entire time? At least I hope I 
understood it correctly. At any rate I was shocked. Ingenious twist. The 
film itself is very good, though it's not as good as Tarkovsky's later 
films and it really doesn't feel like Tarkovsky at all. It stroke me as a 
little pretentious at times, and the subplots ultimately add up to very 
little. Besides, the video quality is terrible-blacks are blocky and muddy, 
pixellation is annoying, etc. Guess I'll have to buy the Criterion 
blu-ray...﻿

comments.author: Ragify7

comments.text:
Yeah, no, that was not Tarkovsky's intention at all.  The directing is 
very, very clear in showing her disinterest throughout the film.  The scene 
is interesting, but the average viewer is more than capable of not 
misinterpreting it as grossly as you have, regardless of whether it is now 
or half a century in the past.
comments.author: liamliam1234liam

comments.text:
+liamliam1234liam the audience in 1962 - and no doubt that was Tarkovsky's 
intention - saw that scene as cute. It's only now, in 2015, in these 
feminist times, that we see the scene as quasi-rape.
comments.author: Andres Karel

comments.text:
+Andres Karel You are kind-of clueless. He is a captain. She is a nurse's 
assistant. This kind-of stuff happens all the time in the military now - 
imagine what it would have been like in 1940s Russia. You cannot say no. 
You cannot protest. He has power over her, and to resist would be 
potentially dangerous.
comments.author: liamliam1234liam

comments.text:
+Mariam El Sadr I understand your point, but while it surprised her, it 
doesn't seem to be a forced kiss, certainly she does not protest it. And 
why would she agree to have a walk in the forest with him in the first 
place if the didn't have some interest in him
comments.author: Andres Karel

comments.text:
+Andres Karel Not cute at all! The scene is fantastically shot but notice 
how Masha is not interested in Kholin and he unsuccessfully persuades and 
fools her the entire time. I interpret this images rather as a forced kiss 
that represents the "role" and vulnerability of civilians during a war.
comments.author: Mariam El Sadr

Охренеть, вот это финал... как вокруг Ивана все то, чего не будет для него, 
но что СТАЛО для других, он сражался ЗА ВСЕ и ДЛЯ ВСЕХ, за все и для всех, 
за все и для всех... и (если не врут мои глаза) бежит, бежит по воде, 
отражая героический переход с берега на берег в самом начале... вообще, не 
очень люблю Тарковского (Рублев для меня примечателен только последней 
историей про колокол, и Зеркало визуальной красотой... а Солярис со

comments.author: fatima marinho

comments.text:
First of all, no one invented montage.  It is like Columbus discovering 
America after the birds and the bees and the indians.  The  sequence is 
only important on a mortal frame work of beginning and end of the search 
for spices and gold.  Movies always did what ever they did, Eisenstein just 
wanted to claim it for his own,  just like Columbus.   I think it is much 
more fruitful to look at a movie as if it came right out of the womb of the 
director.  Never fixate on the tools, if you buy into to the film class 
talks, one will not appreciate what the movie is offering, a timeless time 
machine. ﻿
comments.author: Jesse Akaike

comments.author: tchhigh

comments.text: thought-provoking﻿
comments.author: max bruno

comments.text:
Well I finally lost my Tarkovsky virginity and I must say that I am very 
impressed. I am a big fan of war films but of all the great war epics such 
as Private Ryan, Gone with the Wind, Casablanca, Patton, etc., I have never 
seen one which told the story from the perspective of a child. Inventive 
and ingenious, this movie also features some of the best cinematography I 
have ever seen.

I appreciate and respect Tarkovsky's influences and homages, most notably 
to Orson Welles, with many shots being heavily influenced by his works. 
Some of the scenes, particularly in the beginning and end, seemed to be 
heavily based off of the 1920's Expressionist movement, with the Soviet 
director channeling the thought processes of the likes of Weine and Murnau. 
I also appreciate the tug of war between Anderi Tarkovsky and Ingmar 
Bergman. The two directors consider the other the best and their favorite 
and if you study their careers you will notice the mutual influence shared 
by the two.

All in all this was an incredible picture and I plan on watching many, many 
more films from Tarkovsky in the future. I think that Anderi Rublev will be 
my next endeavor into the world of the pinnacle of Russian cinema. Much 
respect to Eisenstein, but I think this beat out Pot'yomkin.﻿
comments.author: FenceDaGreat

comments.text:
+hjarten Speaking of horrific WW2 films from a child's perspective you must 
see Forbidden Games. I forget the director but it's a French film. The girl 
in the movie delivers the greatest acting from a child I've ever seen. Even 
so, I have a hard time ranking her considering she was LITERALLY 5 years 
old when she did it. 99% of adult actors can't deliver such sadness and raw 
emotion, even though she was too young to grasp to seriousness of the film.

Aside from her, I gotta go with Jean Pierre-Leaud as my favorite child 
actor. The scene in The 400 Blows where he's being interviewed by the cops 
seems so genuine I have to question whether or not his actual childhood was 
somewhat similar to the film.
comments.author: FenceDaGreat

comments.text:
+Michael Colello Never heard of it, I'll look into it, it has great reviews 
so I'll have to check it out. The cool thing about Ivan is that in my 
country (US) and really the entire west we learn so much about the western 
side of WW2 and oftentimes neglect the Russian perspective which was HUGE 
in defeating the Nazis. The perspective of a child makes it even more 
unique and the direction and cinematography makes it the most unique of all.
comments.author: FenceDaGreat

comments.text:
Well then you have to see the French classic 'Jeux interdits' from 1952. A 
very good film. May not seem horrific in image, but it is in words.
comments.author: Jeffery Frisone

comments.text: hjarten nailed it - "Come and See" is the best of the best.
comments.author: Michael Colello

comments.text:
Here is a list of my top 4 Russian films: 

'The Thief' • The actors were great.  The kid nailed it (nothing worse then 
a poorly cast film, especially if it has a kid who can't act.)  The main 
actor; think - Russian version of William Holden.

'Dark Eyes' • I got a soft spot for Mikhalkov, and Mastroianni, who was 
nominated for best actor Oscar. 

'Moscow Does not Believe in Tears' • It is really a period peace; Russia 
after the war and the arcs of three female  friends lives during the Soviet 
era.  (Russian peacetime story built like 'Soldier of Orange', the Dutch 
war story.)

'Russian Ark' • I doubt that another film will ever match it's 
technical/artistic achievement:  Entire film done one take.  And the ending 
lines are unparalleled; Terrence Malick must of ate his heart out when he 
viewed it.
comments.author: hjarten

comments.text: +hjarten I have that on my watchlist, will watch it soon.
comments.author: ZeppelinBigFan

comments.text:
Yeah you might want to find and watch "Come and See".  Bucolic life then 
the Nazis arrive.  Just one child's/village's nightmare.  But be advised:  
It is horrific.
comments.author: hjarten

comments.text:
+ZeppelinBigFan In terms of Russian directors, if it isn't Tarkovsky it's 
Eisenstein so I respect your opinion. Po'tyomkin is one of my favorite 
silent films and is arguably the best silent film ever, although movies 
like Metropolis, Caligari and City Lights can argue that point.

I'd love to tell you to watch more Tarkovsky films (which you should 
anyways) but Ivan's Childhood is my favorite of his I've seen so I can't 
say he's done better. "Andrei Rublyov" is another great film by Tarkovsky. 
Some say it's better than Ivan's Childhood. I don't think so and it lacks 
the cinematographic and expressionist work of Ivan as well as the emotion 
and suspense in the acting but I will concede that the writing is better 
and the overall direction of Rublyov seems to be more closely-knit.
comments.author: FenceDaGreat

comments.text:
I just popped my Tarkovsky cherry today. I agree, it was amazing, however I 
have to say that Eisenstein's Potemkin was better. The best silent film 
I've ever seen.
comments.author: ZeppelinBigFan

comments.text:
"В Ивановом детстве я пытался анализировать состояние человека, на которого 
воздействует война. Если человек разрушается, то происходит нарушение 
логического развития, особенно, когда это касается психики ребенка. Герой 
фильма сразу представился мне как характер разрушенный, сдвинутый войной. 
Бесконечно много, все что свойственно возрасту Ивана, безвозвратно ушло из 
его жизни. А за счет всего потерянного – приобретенное, как злой дар войны, 
сконцентрировалось в нем и напряглось"(А.Тарковский)﻿
comments.author: Владимир Собко

comments.text:
Philippe, no mezcles religión con realidad, ni menos con la historia. La fe 
va por un lado y los hombres vamos por otro. La historia ni siquiera 
observa como tema a la religión porque no posee sustancia de estudio. Lo 
que si nos ocupa, es el estudio de tus ideas mágico religiosas, los efectos 
que esto tenga en todos, tanto religiosos como no religiosos… Ten cuidado. 
Saludos
comments.author: Victor Hugo Alvarado Gallardo

comments.text:
It is a beautiful advertising! Why are not more beautiful Nazi movies? In

... The Riefenstahl, for the simple fact of being a Nazi, no less than 
anyone. Then: They are only prejudices that make them superior to 
appreciate this film. Art is art or art propaganda regardless of their 
purpose, Soviet Yankee ... Nazi propaganda. Beautiful advertising ...

comments.text:
¡¡¡Las películas de Tarkovski son muy hermosas, pero las vulgarizar como si

comments.text:
Beautiful movie ... But, you better go see movies and read more books, 
fewer films especially Yankees, who are handling more, and when to see 
works of art, vulgarizas. This movie is very good, I like the films of 
Tarkovsky, but is only one of many views of history, in addition, made 
​​poetry. There is absolute truth as many take it, however beautiful it may 
be not. Calm down and think it's all ... Do not be naive. Cheers and see 
you soon ...
comments.author: Victor Hugo Alvarado Gallardo

comments.text:
Bella película… Pero, mejor ve memos películas y lee más libros, menos 
películas yanquis sobretodo, que son las que manipulan más, y al momento de 
ver obras de arte, las vulgarizas. Esta película es muy buena, a mí me 
gustan las películas de Tarkovski, pero solo es una de muchas visiones de 
la historia, además, esta poetizada. No es la verdad absoluta como muchos 
la toman, por muy bella que sea no lo es. Tranquilízate y reflexiona, es 
todo… No sea ingenuo. Saludos y hasta pronto…
comments.author: Victor Hugo Alvarado Gallardo

comments.text:
Nada de propaganda. A Krushchev no le gusto. El grito "NOSOTROS NUNCA 
USAMOS NINO PARA TRABAJO PELIGROSO DE ESPIONAJE!!!" Mentira del diablo! Que 
DIOS reprenda en el nombre de JESUS CRISTO! Ninos fueron usados y esta 
pelicula dice la verdad. DIOS TE BENDIGA VARON!!!
comments.author: Philippe Renaud

comments.text:
Prostite menya. U moiu ruskuyu nie pomnie nechivo... For me, this was 
Tarkovsky's best movie (along with STALKER). It is profound... but he DOES 
remember there is an audience watching... an audience who must understand 
what is going on. My parents and grand-parents raised me to learn the 
lessons of WWII (and what caused it). Great movie. The boy is actually 16. 
He plays the bell maker in ANDREI RUBLEV (the best part of that movie).
comments.author: Philippe Renaud

comments.text:
I do not believe 2784035159 meant to praise stalin, but the Russian people 
themselves who won IN SPITE OF the NKVD and stalin. We should have listened 
to Churchill. He wanted to see these two evil men lascerate each other 
until neither one could stand up... and then have the Western allies land 
in GREECE (to stop stalin) and FRANCE for the knocking blow to hitler. That 
would have been a good play... but at the price of too many lives. So we 
listened to Roosevelt instead...
comments.author: Philippe Renaud

comments.text: ...Sorry... were IN the Resistance (can't type!).
comments.author: Philippe Renaud

comments.text:
The relentlessness of the Russian people is admirable. My Mom and her 
father were the Resistance. My Paternal Grand-Father landed in NORMANDY 
with LECLERC. Ya tebya ponimayu. Shmert fashistam (both of the dark and red 
kind).
comments.author: Philippe Renaud

αέρα στο πρόσωπό μου, τον ιδρώτα στο μέτωπό μου, την λάσπη στα πόδια μου, 
την άμμο στα πέλματά μου, τον φόβο στην ραχοκοκκαλιά μου. Για μένα δεν 
είναι μια πνευματική ενασχόληση, είναι μια τελείως φυσική εμπειρία

we the people do weary of war but the elites cant get enough, they have the

comments.text:
I remember as a child there -50's- shopping with my Mother asking her why 
the drinking fountain said "whites only".My friends &I would walk across 
the bridge, (the 60's) go down town to Hudsons, & I went to lots of ball 
games at Briggs & Hockey at Olympia, pic nics at Belle isle, Bob-Lo, etc. 
The riots in 67 ended most of that for us, & I seldom went back. No longer 
near there but I hope Detroit can recover.Many people trying to help, & 
that city is not alone in its troubles Best of luck Peace
comments.author: ziggy swartz

comments.text:
I grew up in the city, but now live in the suburbs, where life goes on. 
When I was a kid, we used to ride our bikes across the Ambassador Bridge to 
visit Windsor just for fun. Hard to believe now. It was great to hear from 
you.
comments.author: Mike Wilhelm

comments.text:
Yes- thanks. Are you in Detroit? I grew up in Windsor, and am in tears with 
what has happened to Detroit, and worry about the future of its people. 
Anyway, the wars will keep on happening, for oil, for religion, for 
control, for ideology and politics. When we were throwing stones or using 
broadswords, it was fun and games. Now with so many nuclear weapons and 
unstable or aggressive countries, it puts us on track for extinction.
comments.author: ziggy swartz

comments.text: What a pity that that's what it takes to fully understand the horror of war.
comments.author: Mike Wilhelm

comments.text: good comment
comments.author: Sathiyan Sekaran

comments.text:
Brilliant. Horrifying. Tragic. It was the Russians that defeated the German 
army in Europe- Stalingrad was the start of their defeat, though after 
Montgomery defeated Rommel just prior to that, the handwriting was on the 
wall. How many little Ivan's and Tatyana's slaughtered, Johnnies and Marys 
& Hans' and all the rest, from Coventry& Moscow& Dresden & Hiroshima & on & 
on. Perhaps if the Americans had suffered what the Russians, & Europeans 
did they'd be much less gung ho about war.
comments.author: ziggy swartz

comments.text: though not for the freedom of eastern europe, apparently.
comments.author: hojima

comments.text:
This movie is a masterpiece. I am not fond of war movies, generally, but 
having been born of two parents who experienced WWII, I felt emotionally 
involved from the first scene to the last. Andrej Tarkovskij is a great 
director, but I also applaud the cameraman who did an excellent job. War is 
one of the dumbest and most criminal inventions of the human being. And 
children are the first victims. If they can survive, they will be marked 
for life.
comments.author: acintoli

comments.text:
*Ivan's Childhood by Andrei Tarkovsky* 
First Film by the prophet of modern cinema Andrei Tarkovsky
While *Sergei Eisenstein* literally wrote the grammar of cinema by 
inventing *Montage*, Tarkovsky found the true calling of cinema with his 
exposition of long shot where the roving camera wanders examining stuff and 
through its eyes reach into the heart and soul of the protagonist. Through 
him film became what it was meant to be, the purveyor of dreams. All other 
developments in cinema are borrowed from other visual and literary 
developments.﻿
comments.author: Able Lawrence

comments.text:

is something I did not understand?
